data.text: Has Anyone Toured with a Folding Bicycle?
Has anyone travelled with a foldie? Most had mTB or roadie. Any experience to share on pros and cons. Can foldie ever make it?

We cycle tour with Bike Friday folding bikes. Find them fabulous. They pack into a Samsonite suitcase which if we want can be converted into a trailer. Below is a picture of the Bike Friday set up. (Not my photo, I don't have a photo of my newest Bike Friday on this device).
data.author: Jenny Currie

data.text: this is sooooo cool
data.author: Maria Belton

data.text: I commute with a 26 inch folding bike , great for trains busses . Google Montague para trouper bike . Believe it would also make a good touring bike . I am against small wheel bikes , will not ride any thing smaller than a 26'
data.author: Garth Berry

data.text: On normal roads yes dont be going graveling or off roading with them fully loaded or take a trailer since there isnt alot of panier options
data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: 14,000 km on a Dahon Mariner that I put a 2x front chainring on.
data.author: Tristan Natsirt

data.text: I highly recommend having a custom back wheel built if you're using 20-in wheels. The rider's weight is shifted pretty far back on a folding bike, and add all the luggage weight, and you can have some problems. Destroyed the stock wheel, destroyed a replacement wheel, and finally got a custom wheel built on velocity cliffhanger rims and Shimano 105 hubs. It's been perfect ever since.
data.author: Tristan Natsirt

data.text: Thanks man. But that‚Äôs probably seat suspension of some form that may helps keep the bike in proper function. A foldie is probably meant for a shorter tours. Your 14000 km is cross alantic that explains the destructionsü§£

data.text: Bike Friday does a folding Touring bike.
data.author: Martin Fano

data.text: Many many people tour on folding bikes, especially Bike Friday. They became popular when the cost of taking a bike on a plane skyrocketed and many still use them. I personally prefer a bike with normal-sized wheels (and I believe there are some folders that have such) for when I encounter rougher terrain. I also note that a long-reach rear derailleur comes very close to the ground when the wheels are so small and I‚Äôd be sure to damage it. I have a bike that‚Äôs not a folder but fitted with S&S couplers so the frame comes apart for packing in a 26x26x10 suitcase (maximum size without being oversized). The couplers are the only thing I regret about my choices for that bike as, even with 4 round trips to Europe, I still haven‚Äôt broken even on the cost of the couplers and case, plus there‚Äôs the additional weight.
data.author: Jacquie Gaudet

data.text: I have a montague hybrid folding bike and took it's rather large bag. I cycled all day, arrived outside the hotel very hot and sweaty, folded up the bike and lugged it up stairs into the hotel. Lightweight it isn't but it meant that I had a great cycling holiday on pretty rugged terrain.
data.author: Theresa Finking

data.text: Did two tours on a Bike Friday...and was uncomfortable with the geometry, the relative distance between me and the center of the front wheel in downhill situations, bordering on dangerous a couple of times. A local frame builder explained that instability to me. A learning experience $$$$. sold the bike and donated the $$$$ to the local Bikeworks programs. On one trip I met a tourer with a Tern with 26" wheels. I tried it and was impressed, handled much better. Felt safe.
data.author: Mark V Hillman

data.text: Just make sure everything is tight. I seen a guy‚Äôs come apart going downhill in Scotland. Serious, was an ambulance job. üòè
data.author: Thomas Magowan O'Moore

data.text: yea, folding mostly doesn't have a real place in mtb. There may be a few decent models, but a hinge in the frame really knocks down structural integrity.
data.author: Jared O'Moore-Klopf

data.text: And he was on ‚Äòroad‚Äô on the NC 500 in North West Scotland. üòè Obviously done something wrong. Off road straight into a wall and into a field. He was very badly injured.

data.text: I used only foldie for trips less than one week as I found it was very tiring using foldie for a daily of 80-100km. If it was over a week, I would use my 26‚Äùtouring bike.

data.text: 3 days bike trip around Lake Biwa in Japan
data.author: Norman Tam

data.text: Thank you all for the feedback. My conclusion is more ppl are for >26‚Äù. Foldie has its cost advantage on flight but won‚Äôt cut for the distance with the loads to handle. Will forget about foldie for tours.
data.author: John Chew

data.text: I've read through most of the comments and I think that one thing to keep in mind is that not all folding bikes are the same (in wheel size, geometry and folding mechanism) and some of the againsts are from people who have never even actually ridden them. We love ours and have toured 1000's of km's with full panniers. Different strokes for different folks. Happy touring on whatever you ride. üòä
data.author: Jenny Currie

data.text: Done a couple of 2000km rides, self sufficient, on Brompton cycles.
data.author: John Mellor

data.text: See my profile..a few posts down my page for pictures of two of us on a 2k tour with Brompton folding bikes this June.

data.text: Every Story Has A Beginning, Every Dream Has An Inspiration, But Everyone‚Äôs Way Of Getting There, Is Sometimes Just A Little Different....üåé ‚Ä¢ trade in cryptocurrency and regain your losses.
data.author: Daniel Albert

data.text: Yes you can tour on a folding bike. Great for mixed mode touring, riding, busses, trains, ferries, etc when you don't have the time to do long haul rode days but want to see as many regions of a destination as possible. I own and have toured on a Bike Friday NWT and a KSH F20 JJ. KSH is a ridiculously good bike at a ridiculously cheap price. KSH build elite level BMX so they know a bit about design geometry for 406 (20") wheeled bikes, stable and comfortable with all standard off the shelf components. Reynolds Chromoly tubing and factory built wheels from the same factory they build their comp BMX wheels.
data.author: Trevor Piper
